Sadly, I have no income to provide said dollars. Anyway, I wanted to talk about something else. Perhaps I'll rant about my unemployment another time...

Today I walked over to Jon's house, to play D&D, and I was startled when I realized I had walked by two people on a crowded sidewalk without feeling any real sort of discomfort. I consider this a real achievement for me, for some reason, despite having done nothing to acquire this seemingly supernatural power. Most of my life, though, I have felt horribly uncomfortable when thrust into any situation where I had to deal on a personal level with any strangers. This is such a bad discomfort it has always included even passing people in hallways. I never know what to do. Do I look at them? Do I look down, pretending not to see them? Smile? Nod my head? Do both? Neither? Do I glance at them, acknowledging their existance, then quickly look away, as if to say "I know you're there, but you mean nothing to me"? Should I keep my hands in my pockets? Walk purposefully? I just don't know. Sometimes my discomfort is so bad I do things like pretend to yawn or cough, just so that I'm sort of "exempted" from having to make any sort of acknowledgement, because I'm somehow busied by my body's functions. But anyway, today I walked past two people. And I'd passed the second man and then realized I'd really felt nothing. It was... ...well, nothing, really, and I was happy. It was like putting a neurosis in a box.

On another note, though... I hate when people talk over me. It drives me berserk. I hate being interrupted. I hate being spoken over. So much. And it happens to me more than I feel it does to many other people. Perhaps it's because I'm often very soft spoken. Or maybe I'm just not INTERESTING. I dunno. But even online, I feel that people are often much happier to be talking to just about anybody or anything else they can interact with than me. Sigh. Lose one neurosis, find another, perhaps.

Sometimes I wonder why I try.

Like, at all. With everything. What am I doing? Where am I going? Just _how much_ value do I have? Besides the cents you'd get from boiling me into my individual elements, I mean... But am I just wasting my life? Am I just a _waste_ of life?

And why do I only post on my journal when I'm upset?

I just don't understand. I don't understand the world. I'm afraid of dying, but I don't do much with my life. It's all the same monotony every day, and I never make any headway into accomplishing anything. Just what am I doing for anybody? No matter how many compliments I hear, they roll off me like water. I'm unable to accept that I'm in any way a good thing. I feel like an anvil in the ocean, pulling down the people stubborn enough to cling to me. 

I don't understand people. I don't... get it. I can't take people for face value anymore. I can't figure out their thoughts and I get frustrated and distance myself. I'm too sensitive, and I don't like to be hurt, at all. I just... I can't cope, some days. And some days, I'm content to slide into this dull, dreary existence and just 'be'. 

Fuck.

I don't feel well. No matter how early I sleep, no matter how late I awaken, I always feel tired. I don't think I've been sleeping _deeply_ for a long time now. My eyes burn. And I always half remember things in the night, like my cat crawling over me or awakening to hear a verse of a song left on my computer. Hearing cars race by my window - four lanes of pavement less than a hundred feet from my window. Perhaps closer to fifty. Maybe less than that, even. I judge distance badly...

And then, strange dreams. Strange, strange dreams. The night before last, it was some mad priest's quest for power by telepathically controlling and mutating the royalty. Last night, I had a party with all my friends in some kind of void hallway, full of doors that lead to strange rooms. They all did things that made me upset or angry and it's probably the closest to a nightmare that I can possibly get. Besides the one where I thought I destroyed the universe. Even _I_ find that fairly scary.

Lately I've just had this surrounding feeling of discontent. Maybe it's a stressful time of year for people in general, and I'm picking up on that too heavily. But it begins to wear on me, I think. 

Yesterday I talked to Gary for the first time, I think. It felt unusual. I mean, usually when I see Gary, it's with Jordan and Bill, and we're all sort of having a free-for-all where we chatter about nonsense and insult each other whimsically. But Jordan had class. Bill went home with Cathy. So Gary and I were left to wander around campus and, of course, went right to our mutual love.

House of the Dead.

Oh yes. The crappy old shooting game from... what? 1997? Old, in video game standards. It was really odd how deep it went, though. It was like we were proving ourselves to one another on this field of battle. I went first. After tearing through most of the game on a single credit, the zombies eventually took me and I had to give up the gun, for lack of quarters. Though, with commentary like "Whoa, like a sniper!" and "That was niiiiiice" as I busted out the headshots, I nodded inwardly with satisfaction. Then, I watched Gary as he began, messed up a little, began again with new quarters. Once he got in his groove, I was impressed - he was the first person I've seen as good at HotD as I am, if not a little better for knowing all the tricks. So, with mutual respect forged, we went and sat in the food court, bitched about things of no consequence, the good old days of gaming, stuff people do, that kinda shit. It wasn't a big deal, really, but I do have a new respect for the guy.

Oh, what else? What else... I suppose my life is fairly dull. I've little to report. We went and saw Dreamcatcher over the weekend, that was fairly cool. "We" meaning Jon, Neil and I... scratch that, me, Jon and Neil (fuck you, proper grammar). Anyway. We went out for a dinner first (I call them 'fancy' dinners, because you have to sit down, order off a menu, and can't supersize it). Although considering we went to Jungle Jim's, found it full, went to My Brother's Place, full again, and eventually settled on Klondike Jake's... I suppose it wasn't fancy, per se. Heheh. Anyway, it was fun and funny, as usual, with Jon once again experimenting with drinks off the alcoholic beverage menu. You'd think he'd have learned after the martini last time ("Oh God, it tastes like perfume."). Anyway. He had some kinda mudslide thing that was actually pretty tasty, but probably because it was full of chocolate and whipped cream. Regardless...

Then we saw Dreamcatcher, which was... fucked up. That's how I best describe it. It didn't make a lot of sense at times, but I don't feel obliged to read the book on the off hope it makes more sense. Overall, the evening cost me almost thirty dollars, but it was worth it to get out and have some fun with friends.

I'd like to see Spirited Away when it comes out, too, just 'cause I usually enjoy Miyazaki (even before he went all Disney on us, dammit). My friend Greg told me he wants in if we go to see it. Another story altogether, there.

Anyway. I don't want to divide my attention between this and IRC anymore (IRC looks like such a happy place suddenly). So, baibai.

Had my first LAN party on the 30th. It was quite a night. I commented to my friend it was a night to remember, so it should be here, I guess. I'd say it was perfect, except for one horrible flaw - at least in my eyes:

The LAN party itself _sucked_.

But everything else? Funfunfun. My parents were good enough to let me have the jeep overnight. So I packed up my goods, computer and XBox, and we journeyed forth to Kris'. Jon followed us in his car, and there was something fun about that, too. Especially the little races - Jon's car doesn't stand a chance against the jeep, and it's quite fun. Regardless, we picked up Kris' stuff, and with two carloads full of electronics off we went to grab some dinner.

Jon and Kris and I went to Jungle Jim's, and ordered a kitchen sink and two pounds of insanity wings. We should have ordered one. We'd never had them before, but Jon and I swore we'd try them next time we were there. BIG MISTAKE. We should've known when they made us sign liability waivers these things were NAS-TY. But, stupid us, we ate 'em anyway! Well. About five of them. HO-LEE SHIT. Now, I can hold my own against spicy food. Which is why I managed to eat three before I called it quits. Jon ate half of one. And poor Kris, who had only bitten off a tiny bit of one before deciding it was way too hot for him, accidentally picked it up against in place of a normal buffalo wing and devoured the whole thing before he knew what was going on. When he suddenly shrieked "I ATE THE WRONG ONE!" and started going all teary eyed, it was all Jon and I could do not to crumple out of the booth laughing. The waitress serving us looking so genuinely concerned for him, and he kept making these funny noises and looking at us with such horror. It was cruel to laugh, but he knew it was funny, and we did too. We all laughed about it later. Since she was so nice, we left that waitress a big tip. I also ordered dessert from Jungle Jim's for the first time ever - we all decided after those wings, we needed some dairy on our ravaged tongues. Next time, we're sticking to the nice, tame, tasty suicide wings.

So then it was off to the LAN party. Which, like I said, sucked. I'm not doing that again for a long time. It was horribly planned. We all brought enough hardware, but nobody planned for software problems. As a result, it turned mostly into a Quake-fest, which was because most of the people there were "l33t quakers". I only went under the condition it WOULDN'T be all Quake. Ugh. Also, power supplies weren't considered, and the room we'd commandeered was discovered to be a single circuit room. Not enough for six computers, a hub, and an XBox with TV. Not nearly. We had to run all kinds of extension cords. And in the end, it wasn't exactly fun, I found. Blah. And at 8am, I hauled my sorry ass and my hardware back home, and collapsed into bed.

But prior to that, at about 1 am, we all went out for McDonald's. And that was fun. We were all tired and weird, by then. The drive-through was the only thing open, so we had to go through that. But everybody had debit cards, and thus it was going to be a big hassle to place the order. I refused to do it, as the driver, and told Gary (who was in the driver side rear) he had to. He wouldn't either. So with both people on that side refusing to do it, I came up with the only viable solution.

So we went through the drive through backwards, and Kris placed the order. To our merit, I did go through forward to the window, but when the girl saw us back around the building and turn around so we'd be going straight, she made the funniest face. After much typing of PIN numbers, we had our food and darted on back to the doomed party. I watched Transformers on my computer while I sucked on my milkshake, and was happy, for a time.

But, by 8 am, the thrill was gone. The LAN party sucked, otherwise, and I lost my monitor power cord. I took the one Jordan gave me, because he was the one who'd been nice enough to lose mine. When he finds it, I'll trade back. Anyway. It was a great night, excluding the party itself, which left me drained and grouchy by the time I crumpled into bed at 8:30 or so. I ended up sleeping all day yesterday, and missed any calls that came in (because my father was so nice as to not answer the phone at all). So for new years eve, I sat at home, alone, and did squat. Which was also nicely depressing. 

Basically, the party left me with one dire need - I've got to do something social, because I'm just lonely and depressed as a result of it. Next time we have a LAN party? I'm playing XBox.

I'm nineteen and my friends and I still burp crudely at each other. *grin* So, what am I saying? I'm not sure. A girl who's... sort of... guyish. But feminine. Does that exist? I think so. A girl who can watch Dead or Alive 3 and say "Jeez, how does she WALK with those knockers?" rather than "I can't believe you play this, guys are pigs." Heh. Maybe I'm just insane. But that leads me to something really, really important to me. I have a really bad ego, in most respects. I have all the self esteem of a shoe. So in trying to define a perfect woman, I think more about her ability to accept what I consider my 'faults'. Or rather, accept me for me. I don't want someone who's out to change me from a social reject geek into Joe Average or Mr. Cool. I like being a social reject geek. I like to play video games. Watch cartoons. Role play, MUD, draw anime. Act stupid with my friends WITHOUT alcohol. Listen to obscure music, from power metal to bouncy dancy techno. Wear black and baby talk to my cat. I don't expect a girl to sit down and PLAY those games, to role play with me, or dance to my music (though if she did that would be awesome! ^_^). But just accept that's the things I do. Some of my friends often go out with girls who go on about how stupid video games are, how geeky RP is, how much this music or that music sucks, and so forth. I wouldn't be able to bear it. Those things define me. So, let's do a tally so I can keep this all straight. Short, average girl with hair. Must like to laugh, not be frustratingly girly, and like me for me. What else was there? Oh, yes. I like someone deep. Deep and intelligent. Someone I can sit down and have a long, fulfilling conversation with. Someone who can listen to some obscure ballad I've got tucked away on my drive and be moved by it. Who can voice emotions and explore feelings powerfully. Someone who can experience the world in such an array of sentiments, a vast spectrum of awarenesses, that they can see the darks and lights and their complicated interplay, and inquire as to if it is beautiful or hideous. Someone who is both strong to reality, and quietly vulnerable. I find that... vastly alluring. Because it is much like myself. Why, exactly? I do not know. A person with quiet pain captures my heart more powerfully than anything else I've mentioned here. That's not to say I want someone depressed and hurt - but rather, I want someone who can take that hurt and reach out to me with it. I ache, always, to feel important and useful and needed to other people. The person who had the greatest fraction of my affection would, simply put, have to need me. As much as I would need them. Because... when two people _need_ each other to be happy, it makes them two parts of the same whole. Two puzzle pieces that, while perhaps not fitting perfectly, nonetheless fill the holes in one another. So... I don't know why I've typed all this. But it feels good to have it all down. So it's not just bouncing around aimlessly in my mind. Reading over it all, I do feel hypocritical, and selfish. But I suppose it's just another one of those reasons I'm single. That and being so anti-social. Not that I hate people. I just don't go out of my way to be around them, usually. Maybe I'm just lazy or something. Oh well... What do I have to offer anybody, exactly? I don't know. Not a lot, I guess. I don't imagine there's a lot of women who both fit this profile, and find me befitting their own glorious desires. It's all hormones anyway. Fuck you, hormones! Gleh. Heh. Anyway. I've little else to ramble on about, now, I suppose. My current music is from Final Fantasy for those unfamiliar with the artist name. Just more proof what a geek I am.

All I wanted for lunch was soup. Really. But as I walked away I noticed they had (O Glory, Gloriosa!) mozza sticks! MOZZA STICKS! Cheeeese on the inside, horribly friiiied on the outside. One of my greatest culinary weaknesses. But, alas, all they would allow me to do was order the sticks in a basket with other food. I ended up spending four times what I'd intended for three times as much food! More even! At least it had shrimp and chicken in it, but gawd. No supper for me today. In fact, I even had to throw out most of the fries. Which, really, was okay, I guess. The fries in our school cafeteria kind of suck. Plus, I get a sort of guilty pleasure when I throw out food. Why? Good question!

I never used to have any problem with food going to waste. I'd yell at people who'd throw out their sandwich and complain they were hungry, of course, but otherwise, big deal. So you're full and half a sandwich goes to waste. My ex was in fact the one who put this notion of using all food in my head. And despite the fact we've been broken up well over a year now, it's always stuck with me.

In fact, I find myself lately thinking a lot about that defunct relationship. It's not like I count on getting back together with her, and I'm sure I'm over it. But it's sort of like... you know when you'd make those little play-doh men (was that just me?) by making a ball of dough, and then sticking a body on it? The sphere was as perfect as little hands can make it. And then, you stuck on the body. Which more often than not, fell off. But it always left that spot on the sphere were something should be. And short of remolding the ball, there was no way to get it back to perfect.

Sort of the same deal. I think I just miss having someone 'significant', as they put it. Someone you can tell all your secrets to. Who you can curl up to in front of a TV - laughing at stupid things, like cartoons and 70s sitcoms. Someone warm who's just there for you. I know a part of me largely misses the close _physical_ interactions, but more than that, it's just... like this void, where a best friend belongs.

I know I've got a handful of really, truly close good friends. And I thank my luck I have them just about every day. But it's not the same. I think any one of them would understand that. It's nice to just curl up close to someone, and share private things in quiet murmurs, to tease and chide and know in the end you'll be as close or closer for it. 

What I really miss most of all, I think, is someone who accepted me for all the faults that make me cringe from myself. I'm a big video game addict, I confess. I'm not athletic by any means, and even less now that my friends and I see each other so rarely (note to self: buy basketball!). I watch cartoons (not just anime, but cartoons of all flavour!). And I draw busty anime women all the time. Yes, I admit it! I LIKE to draw big chested women. Also small chested women. And short women, tall women, cute ones, angry ones, all sorts. I just think women are pretty. Can you blame me? They are.

What was I going on about, anyway? Ah, I lament, endlessly. I had something to end that on, but it's gone. Oh well.

<Edit!> With added time to think about it, there was one thing I was thinking of...
Sometimes, I really wish I could be like so many of the other guys I know. I know plenty of people who go through girlfriends like sneakers. Even one or two who do it not out of affection but the simple need to have a girlfriend. Some days, I really wish I was like that. To view it all as something so simply necessary as milk in the fridge. Bah. But no, that's not how I am, is it? I feel relationships are important, and should really mean something deep and powerful. Not something you dash into. And I don't believe in beginning a relationship with a stranger. This "I have a new girlfriend I just met" crap doesn't fly with me. If you can't be a friend with your potential partner, then how can you ever love them? </edit!>

Though that little tirade really did remind me of something else. Sometimes, I feel really stupid for how important I feel video games are to me. I have more games than anyone I know. But I love it. Like role play, it's a chance for me to roam a world far more interesting than my own. What's wrong with that, anyway? Meh.

There's a girl in my school (I just saw her walk by, which reminds me of this), that did something really nice for me. She didn't realize it. Let me explain. My sketchbook has a cover. A very bland cover - or it was, until I drew on it. It now sports the profile of some random anime woman (it was to be Lotus, but didn't turn out), and then along the bottom has super-deformed (or chibi, or kawaii, or baby-style, what have you) renditions of a number of my other characters. Lotus, Shikei, Zayken, Deroth, Synna, and most importantly to this story, Pharris. So, yeah. This girl sees my book and is chittering gleefully over the cute little people at the bottom. She picks out Pharris in particular and dubs him "shady little dude" and goes on about how cute he is. Cute and shady. It made me laugh.

More importantly, later on, when I saw her again, she pointed to my book and went "shady little dude! So cute!" and continues to make references to shady little dude. It just reminds me that I can make an impression that lasts in someone else's mind, which in a lot of ways really means a lot to me. I'd rather be known than wealthy. The fact that people can set aside a part of their memory for me makes me feel gushy. Go see how much I hate the world today! LOLOLOL, I really hate everyone today! Go see!" Like... die. Ahem.

But, a certain someone (who will remain nameless, and is aware of their own identity) had a particularly interesting journal that made me sit, read it all, and go "wow", without any request to do so. And, I suppose they could be theraputic, and a good place to say what needs saying. All that, uh, said (redundancy ho!), I suppose I should... say something.

So. I'm Brian. I prefer Bri. Everyone cool calls me Bri. Well, that's not to say calling me Bri makes you cool. Pardon me, I fly into tangents. Most of the time I'm Pharris. I like that better again. 

Because, and I feel it's important to get this defined right up front, I'm something of a dual personality. Sometimes I think it's amazing I haven't developed a complex. It really depends a lot on my surroundings, my situation, and my company. Sometimes I'm quiet, polite, sheepish, and fidgety. I'd rather sit and draw and avoid eye contact than say a word.

And then, when I'm comfortable, I'm chatty, full of jokes, and overall fairly social. 

You know, I have more 'personalities' than that, even. Because when I'm with my close, real life friends, I can get loud and wild, sarcastic and crude and just off the wall. Just because, usually, that's how we are when we all get together. We're good people, we're just a bit insane.

And, I must confess, when presented with someone who can contest with myself, I can be a real pervert too. I've got more lewd jokes in my filthy mind than I dare consider - but, of course, this is another aspect of me that appears purely based on the audience. I've had people sincerely surprised by how filthy minded I can be. It usually surprises me they didn't expect it. Oh well. I guess my mind is sort of like that. Nice to visit, strange to live in. Too many windows painted black.
